conclusion: Initial position and direction of car A entering from the right side of the image moving towards the left.
Assumption of moderate initial speed for the car due to lack of explicit indication.
Collision and deflection effects where car transfers kinetic energy to block causing change in direction and speed.
Car A is heading towards the orange block closest to its path.
Upon collision, car will push orange block forward and deflect to the left due to angle of impact.
Car will continue moving leftward and may hit the next block in its path, another orange block.
Second collision causes car to lose speed and possibly deflect further left.
Depending on remaining speed and direction, car might hit more blocks, reducing speed and altering trajectory.
Car may eventually come to a stop near the cluster of blocks or between them if it continues to lose speed.
Car likely to stop near the center of the cluster of blocks after losing enough speed from collisions.
Exact stop position depends on specific angles and speeds after each collision, within the group of blocks.
Final answer: Car A will collide with orange blocks first, then potentially other nearby blocks, and stop near the center of the cluster of blocks.
